title: Could I travel alone at 16 years old in the USA? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the ATA. Yes you can, but to get a green card you are probably going to need to be a so called “alien of extraordinary ability” with significant public acclaim in some field. To achieve that level of acclaim at such a young age it will often be in fields like sports or performing arts. Examples of well known immigrants who came to the US under age 18 are Monica Seles and Justin Bieber. If you aren’t coming with that level of “extraordinary ability” it is going to be really tough to qualify for a green card before age 18, since getting the education, work experience, and going through the process takes years—even if you are from a country where there aren’t long backlogs. It will be very hard to get all that done before 18. It is more plausible, for most people, to come to the US before age 18 on a student visa, but that will require money to do. In any case it will be much easier to do if done with the blessings of your parents, even if they don’t accompany you, because someone under 18 can’t sign enforceable contracts in the USA, so you will need some kind of adult support.

Yes, minors are allowed to travel to the US by themselves. Here are the two options: Your parent(s)/guardian(s) may arrange unaccompanied minor (UM) service with an airline. However, there must be somebody dropping you off and picking you up at the airport.With a legal formal letter of permission from your parents, you can travel to the US without using the UM service. Just make sure you bring it and show it at the Border Control. Although not necessary, it is best that somebody picks you up to reassure the Border Control agent that you will not be completely on your own!NB: It also depends on where you are starting your journey from. Certain countries, like South Africa, require its underage citizens (or any underage passengers) and their parents/guardians to submit certain documents (e.g. a copy of your birth certificate) prior to boarding the flight.

I was in basic training when I was 17, so the question made me scratch me head, until I remember that my parents had to sign for me to enlist, which was the equivalent of court order emancipating a minor. I won’t recover what the others said, because they are correct. MY only advice it that you make sure you are comfortable with their maturity level, because they will be responsible for making it to the gate and boarding themselves, and because alcohol is served free on overseas flights. Your child would be listed as an unaccompanied minor on the flight manifest, but I can assure you that the cabin crew is not checking that seat by seat when taking drink orders. Arriving at the U.S. Customs counter intoxicated is not the best way for a 17 year old to enter the U.S. They could hold them until a parent or legal guardian arrives to pick them up. Just playing Devil Advocate here, don’t hate me! :)

Sometimes. Some airlines will not allow unaccompanied minors on board. Others like American Airlines, charge an extra fee. Visiting the US under the age of 18 would not be smart in some states. In Nevada or New York for example, someone under the age of 21 cannot check out a hotel room in many cases.  In Washington state you can rent a hotel room at the age 18, but not under the age of 18 still.  I think you would need to have relatives in the US for a realistic way to be housed anywhere. It is impossible to check out hotel rooms under the age of 18 even if you demonstrate the ability to pay.

In addition to the concerns over air travel by unaccompanied minors and trying to negotiate lodging, US Customs does not simply screen that people have their paperwork in order.  Rather, there is an attempt to assess the real intent and reason for the foreigner appearing in front of them. The irregularity of a minor arriving with no adult and meeting no adult as local guardian would be reason to interpret the story of one's plans as questionable. If entry is refused, the airline has to fly the minor back to the origin of the trip.  For that reason, the airline would need satisfactory supporting information about guardianship while in the US, and possibly correspondence through the US embassy authorizing the trip in advance.

I believe so, I have a friend from Denmark who came here to the U.S. for a while while she was 16. She flew in alone but I believe she had relatives waiting here to meet her. There are also foreign exchange students who come here all the time. I assume many, if not most, come alone. The problem is if you plan on coming here, there are requirements such as a tourist visa (some countries have waivers of this requirement). If you plan on staying it’s a much longer and harder process. Also, if you come alone at 17 you’re gonna have a hard time. You can’t get an apartment or rent a hotel room, where would you stay? There’s a lot of logistical issues that arise from your age. These things may impair the safety and enjoyment you experience during your visit.

If you own a car, I do not see why not. I live in Canada, not the US, but the rules are likely similar. When I was 16, I saved up and bought my own car. It was older, but it worked and I traveled everywhere. Another posted mentioned that you cannot rent a hotel room until you are 18. However there other options. Depending on where you are traveling, and the temperatures there, you could pack a tent in you car and stay at camp sites. You could also sleep in your car. I did both of those things when I was young, simply because it was cheaper than getting a hotel room. Good luck and safe travels.

Alone...not very likely if you plan to travel far. You can't rent a car until your in your 20s (depending on service). Can't rent a hotel room until you're 18, and sometimes even older.  :( sorry to break the bad news, but unless you plan on going on day trips, or maybe stay with relatives along the way, travel across the US alone at 16 would be difficult. Although it’s not ideal, and we want you to be safe, it is possible. Please enlist your parents or a seasoned adult traveler to assist you with your planning. I would check out Hostels Worldwide. If you’re in a city with good public transportation, then you don’t need a car. Maybe you can even rent a bike to get around. Some colleges and universities might have programs or availability in the summer. There’s a lot to think about, in order to be safe. You’ve got to make sure you’re very organized about your money and phone, and don’t get yourself into a situation that seems unsafe. Where do you want to travel in the US, and what is your country of origin?

In the U S people under the age of 18 are not allowed to sign contracts. Because of this, you would have to find an adult who can help you. There are many other barriers to simply moving to the U S. It depends on where you are coming from, but you must have a visa to enter. Contact your U S embassy to find out what you need.

Generally the answer is no. Immigrant status for children is usually dependent on the status of their parent. In fact, in general you can’t get on a plane for an international flight alone, without the approval of a parent.

Yes, however many airlines only consider children under 12 as unaccompanied minors for domestic flights and upto 15 years old for international. You can mark a 16–17 as a young traveller so the airline is aware in case of emergency. However they are deemed fit to travel alone at that age. Thanks for the A2A.
